body:
Hi @Raynok  - you wrote me an email about this didnt' you which got lost in my inbox - sorry! Good choice making a ticket ;-)

What do you think about a [command line interface a bit like this](https://code.google.com/p/bwlimit/wiki/bwlimit)?

Hi Nick,
No worries, Alex and Klaus pointed me in the right direction. 
I think, "Absolutely fantastic".

Going to give it a try and will let you. Great Project !!

Hi Nick,
Thank you for the pointer, there is a issue when issuing the command. Windows based computers.

My original command 
rclone.exe copy Software:GLOBALSOFTWARE c:\support\ --transfers=1 -c --bwlimit=100
error: None

Testing command
rclone.exe copy Software:GLOBALSOFTWARE c:\support\ --transfers=1 -c --bwlimit=100 7-21,50"
Error: It is only necessary to use a unique prefix of the subcommand, eg 'mo'for 'move'.
Command copy needs 2 arguments maximum

If its something simple - I do apologize . I've tried use a .bat file with a set variable and got the same error.

That syntax `-bwlimit=100 7-21,50` won't work at the moment, I just wondered what you thought about that syntax?

Namely having a 1 hour granularity and setting it like that.

If we think it is a good idea then we can implement something
The syntax makes sense and pretty simple to grasp though there must be some reference in the documentation ;-) . Setting the 1 hour granularity is perfect - I would do the same. You have my vote :+1:
+1 on this as well. That way while I'm sleeping, rclone can use up all my bandwidth without me having to mess with it.

I whipped up some systemd timers to do this, as well as to make sure folders are automatically backed up.

https://gist.github.com/AlexisEvo/3a803de79332b4e5fb83

It's gross, but it works. :)

Howzit - Still using rlcone and enjoying the new versions.

Alexis :+1: nice one . Didn't understand at first but did some reading. My environments are 99.9% Microsoft.

 I've created a deployment package to distribute rclone to specific computers.

1.) The deployed package creates the folders and shares. Then...
2.) Downloads rclone + config file from google drive.
3.) Initiates the download of the files with a download rate I've set and logs it to a file.
4.) Once the download is complete it uploads the log file with the computer name and timestamp.

This gives me the ability to see the progress across multi pal wan sites and if there are no log files then its either busy downloading still or failed. 

In a nut shell.

Control all the files on google and it mimics at the destinations. I can see the activity logs in google and this allows me to manage and view multi pal wan sites under one plane of glass (not perfect but best effort)

Thought I share how i try use rclone.

Not sure if it's helpful to anyone, but I'm using some rudimentary traffic shaping in Linux to help with bandwidth management while this native capability in rclone is being matured. Here's a link to some info: http://lartc.org/howto/lartc.ratelimit.single.html

Instead of the last line in the example that shapes based on destination IP I'm just shaping based on destination port (443) using this command:

`tc filter add dev $DEV parent 1: protocol ip prio 16 u32 match ip dport 443 0xffff flowid 1:1`

The Linux box I'm using for `rclone sync` commands is dedicated so I'm not too worried about shaping other port 443 traffic. It's hard to shape based on destination IP because most of these cloud services have a multitude of endpoints..

issue.title: Add support to toggle bandwidth limits via SIGUSR2.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Sending rclone a SIGUSR2 signal will toggle the limiter between off and
the limit set with the --bwlimit command-line option.

body:
Why not use a multiple hh:mm,bandwidth type of configuration, having the currently selected bandwidth limits stay until superseded by the next configuration time slot? Something like:

-bwtimes="23:00,0 05:00,3000 08:00,500 20:00,3000"

This means:
- At 5am, switch to 3000
- At 8am, switch to 500
- At 8pm, switch to 3000
- At 11pm, switch to unlimited

Order should be irrelevant.

This format should be easy to parse and provides substantial flexibility with time selection.

@marcopaganini Does that mean you set `--bwlimit` as well as `--bwtimes`? I quite like there being only one command line, so as you suggested, but with the default bwlimit first, so something like `--bwlmit ="500k 23:00,off 05:00,3M 08:00,500k 20:00,3M"` (the `SizeSuffix` parser will parse the `3M` or `off` for you).

That works well, but what is the purpose of the "default" bwlimit in this
case? If we have time slots, we'll always be covered by one of them at a
given time of the day.

On Sun, Oct 30, 2016 at 12:41 PM, Nick Craig-Wood notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @marcopaganini https://github.com/marcopaganini Does that mean you set
> --bwlimit as well as --bwtimes? I quite like there being only one command
> line, so as you suggested, but with the default bwlimit first, so something
> like --bwlmit ="500k 23:00,off 05:00,3M 08:00,500k 20:00,3M" (the
> SizeSuffix parser will parse the 3M or off for you).
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/221#issuecomment-257173633, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AHFMBMNjvJ7mGThIDeo3X-OPc_vfh_NNks5q5PL_gaJpZM4Gi6Lh
> .

@marcopaganini I guess the default limit is what you get until you get to one of the trigger times when the bandwidth limit changes. If you don't have that then you'll have to work out what the current limit should be at any given time.  You'll probably have to work that out anyway though - I imagine a go routine which runs every minute which resets the bwlimit to the limit appropriate to that time.

I think having two flags for setting the bwlimit may confuse people, but I'm happy to go with your suggestion for the exact syntax.

I totally agree with having one flag. I'm just a bit confused about the
"default" bwlimit. The way I was envisioning this was to always scan the
"time slots" and see where we currently fit, setting the bw limiter to that
value.

So, say, someone says 08:00,1M, 23:00,5M, it means that at any point in the
day, we'll be doing 1M (08:00 to 22:59) or 5M (23:00 to 07:59). Of course,
if only one time slot is used, then we'll be at that limit for the whole
day. :)

On Sun, Oct 30, 2016 at 1:01 PM, Nick Craig-Wood notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @marcopaganini https://github.com/marcopaganini I guess the default
> limit is what you get until you get to one of the trigger times when the
> bandwidth limit changes. If you don't have that then you'll have to work
> out what the current limit should be at any given time. You'll probably
> have to work that out anyway though - I imagine a go routine which runs
> every minute which resets the bwlimit to the limit appropriate to that time.
> 
> I think having two flags for setting the bwlimit may confuse people, but
> I'm happy to go with your suggestion for the exact syntax.
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/221#issuecomment-257175047, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AHFMBMpz1OTbmujk8eY7Xm57wgrRbBhyks5q5Pd9gaJpZM4Gi6Lh
> .
@marcopaganini I mis-understood your original plan - I thought it was an ordered list of instructions of time:bwlimit, but I see now that it is a timetable and yes I agree with you now :-)
